item.title: [PI]How to make a .ini file for your server - Briefly Explained!
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:18, topic:427270”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=529971.msg3871327#msg3871327 date=1325363229]
Coelho is right… you didn’t define the variable “p”.

[code=java]Properties p = new Properties();[/java]

Also, you didn’t explain what the benefits of using Property files are. Is loading .ini faster? More efficient? Saying that Property files “save space” is irrelevant and not entirely true.

All in all, great tutorial, but do a little more research before making tutorials like this.[/code]
[/quote]
Will do, thanks. Your better at telling me than:

[quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=529971.msg3870495#msg3870495 date=1325306768]
I have failed to see this “briefly explained.”
[/quote][/quote]
cuz ur shitty title is misleading

Read full topic

Coelho:

You never defined the variable Properties p (or i’m high, you choose), and the file extension from my experience is more commonly “.properties” as opposed to “.ini”. Correct me if i’m wrong, however.

Nope, it’s .ini.

item.title: [PI]How to make a .ini file for your server - Briefly Explained!
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:13, topic:427270”]Why is it centered?

Also, using the Properties class alone with the common syntax would be a plus.

Also, you don’t need to split the lines. You can simply include a newline character

motd=Hello there\nWelcome to etcetcetc\nEnjoy your stay! [/quote]
It’s split as sometimes you want to disable them, and it would be an ease to disable it through a clean notepad file than a file that could give you a big error if 1 mistake is done. I’ll try to make it not centered.

Thanks,
Arham

Read full topic

item.title: [PI]How to make a .ini file for your server - Briefly Explained!
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[center]Your adding:

A simpler way![/center]

[anchor=use][center]Base of use:
[hr]
Project Insanity
[/center]

[font=Trebuchet Ms][center][size=5]How to make a .ini file for your server[/size]

[ul][li][iurl=#introduction]Introduction[/iurl][/li]
[li][iurl=#ini]Your .ini file[/iurl][/li]
[li][iurl=#assistant]PlayerAssistant.java[/iurl][/li]
[li][iurl=#credit]Credit[/iurl][/li][/ul]

[center]__________________________________________________________________________[/center]
[center]__________________________________________________________________________[/center]

[size=2][anchor=introduction]1.0 - Introduction[/size]

Hello everyone! I would like to introduce you to a .ini that is a better way to save some space of your game. In this tutorial, I’ll show you what to put, and give you 1 example. Lets get started!

[center]__________________________________________________________________________[/center]

[size=2][anchor=ini]2.0 - Your .ini file[/size]

Now, we’re gonna make our .ini file. Open your text editing software (I will use notepad). and type whatever. In this example, I’ll put announcements.

//To use this file do the following format:
announcement1= Welcome to Learning's Fun! RSPS
announcement2= To make money you should skill!
//announcement3= it is currently double EXP week-end
announcement4= Be sure to have an amazing time!
announcement5= Latest Update: Update here
//announcement6= fishing guild teleport is near the goblins in lumby
[Announcements]

Just like if you were editing a .java file, you will put // for the things to be X’d out. They will be used later. Save it to your server files.

[iurl=#assistant]Let’s move on to Playerassistant.java![/iurl]

[center]__________________________________________________________________________[/center]

[size=2][anchor=assistant]3.0 - Playerassistant.java[/size]

First of all, add this to the top where all the imports are:

Now in Playerassistant.java, locate:

public int CraftInt, Dcolor, FletchInt;

and above that add something that would connect each line to the server. I think you might be confused of what I’m saying. This is what I’m saying:

[anchor=code][code=java]
Properties p = new Properties();

public void loadAnnouncements()
{
	try
	{
		loadIni();
	
		if (p.getProperty("announcement1").length() > 0) {
			c.sendMessage(p.getProperty("announcement1"));
		}
		if (p.getProperty("announcement2").length() > 0) {
			c.sendMessage(p.getProperty("announcement2"));
		}
		if (p.getProperty("announcement3").length() > 0) {
			c.sendMessage(p.getProperty("announcement3"));
		}
		if (p.getProperty("announcement4").length() > 0) {
			c.sendMessage(p.getProperty("announcement4"));
		}
		if (p.getProperty("announcement5").length() > 0) {
			c.sendMessage(p.getProperty("announcement5"));
		}
		if (p.getProperty("announcement6").length() > 0) {
			c.sendMessage(p.getProperty("announcement6"));
		}
	}
	catch (Exception e)
	{
	}
}

private void loadIni()
    private Properties p = new Properties
{		
	try 
	{
		p.load(new FileInputStream("./Announcements.ini"));
	}
	catch (Exception e)
	{
	}
}

[/code]

Now let me explain this:

Is telling the method what p is.

Is making it load. Announcements is the name of the file. Change that to your .ini files name.

The

	{
		try
		{
			loadIni();

Is calling a method which is located below the first section (

	private void loadIni()
	{		
		try 
		{
			p.load(new FileInputStream("./Announcements.ini"));
		}
		catch (Exception e)
		{
		}
	}

)

			if (p.getProperty("announcement1").length() > 0) {
				c.sendMessage(p.getProperty("announcement1"));
			}

The p.getProperty is getting the code from announcement.ini. Remember this?

announcement1= Welcome to Learning's Fun! RSPS

This line is getting to the server from this:

(p.getProperty("announcement1").length() > 0) {

and this makes it sent:

Now, it is continued throughout the codes. Also, do you remember this?

	{
		try
		{
			loadIni();

with

This is loadIni() (was also mentioned in [iurl=#code]full code[/iurl])

	private void loadIni()
	{		
		try 
		{
			p.load(new FileInputStream("./Announcements.ini"));
		}
		catch (Exception e)
		{
		}
	}

loadIni() is getting the codes for public void loadAnnouncements(). Change:

p.load(new FileInputStream("./Announcements.ini"));

with your name of the notepad file.

So if your notepad files name is ServerName.ini, then you’d do:

And the final result: drum rolls please

[center]__________________________________________________________________________[/center]

[size=2][anchor=credit]3.0 - Credits[/size]

Arham 4: Making this tutorial
RuneLive: For the source that allowed me to see Announcements.ini for the first time.
Moparscape: Best forums.
Clawz Fury: Telling me about the Properties part.
YOU: Reading this guide :).

If you like this, then you’ll probably like these:

[ul][li]A nice clean folder fit for making RSPS work faster - Realm Onwards Program[/li]
[li]Realm Onwards - The RSPS for Newcomers - PI Version - NEW NAME[/li]
[li]Mini-Tutorials and List folder - Part of the: Realm Onwards Program - V2 OUT[/li][/ul]
